summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Health Services Clinical Encounter form documenting the emergency medical response to Jeffrey Epstein in the Special Housing Unit at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It details the resuscitation efforts, including CPR, medications, and intubation, before Epstein was transported to a local emergency room in cardiac arrest.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the medical emergency and resuscitation efforts documented in the clinical encounter form. He was found unresponsive in his cell.

persons.name: Joseph Columbo
persons.context: The provider who generated and signed the clinical encounter documentation detailing the emergency response to Epstein.

connections.description: Columbo documented the clinical encounter and medical response to Epstein's cardiac arrest as a Bureau of Prisons RN.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: A body alarm was activated at 06:35 for a medical emergency. Correctional officers found Jeffrey Epstein unresponsive on the floor of his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with CPR already in progress. He was cold, had bruising around the neck, and showed no signs of life.

events.title: Resuscitation Attempt and Transport
events.description: Medical staff and paramedics performed extensive resuscitation, including CPR, AED (no shock advised), intubation, and administration of epinephrine and sodium bicarbonate. Epstein remained in asystole (no cardiac activity) and was transported to a local emergency room with CPR still in progress.

locations: Special Housing Unit (SHU), 9S (likely cell block designation)
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC NYM/NYC)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on the morning of August 10, 2019, at approximately 6:35 AM.
The clinical notes describe "circumferential Bruising around the neck" and "posterior mottling" upon finding Epstein.

Despite extensive resuscitation efforts by correctional officers, prison medical staff, and paramedics, Epstein showed no cardiac activity (asystole) and was transported to an outside hospital with CPR ongoing.
The document is a primary source medical record generated by RN Joseph Columbo, detailing the timeline and procedures of the emergency response.
